Lori 10 Howard of ScOttSdale,
is countv's Little Miss Hope"
for 1964-65, Robert D. George,
president of the Maricopa County
chapter of the National Cystic
Fibrosis Research Foundation.


Lori, Z, daughter of Mr.. and
Mrs. Glenn E. Howard, 1897
E. Monte Vista, will represent
more than $4,000 American
children and some 800 in central
Arizona who have inherited the
mysterious incurable disease,
when local volunteers conduct the
annual CT fund drive in Sept.


Mr.. George said, "Funds
raised on behalf of CT victims
are used in national research
projects and in the care and
treatment of local CT victims.
A portion of the money is used
to help maintain a CT Clinic
at the Good Samaritan Hospital,
which is under the sponsor ship
of the Junior League Of Phoenix


He added that parents Of CT
children must spend an average
of 500 per month for drugs
alone. cystic fibrosis is the
nations most chronic disease OF
infancy and childhood, ranking
second only to cancer as a child-
killer.

RADNOR. Pa. Negro employ
ment in TV is increasing but Ne
gro leaders still think the pace is
far too slow. TV Guide magazine
reported in its June 20 issue.
Negroes also charge the industry
is extremely timid about using
Negro stars in regular series
and is reluctant to give them
their own programs.


The maya zine, in the first of
two-part survey Of the Negro s
role in television, reported:


/. More Negroes than ever
before are being used as extras
in Hollywood produced TV pro-
grams and being hired by net
works and TV production firms.


2. More Negroes are appearing
in TV commercials and the num-
Der will increase.


8. The NAACP said that while
progress has been made in Ne
gro employment in the industry,
there Is not one Negro employed
by a TV network or station In
a top executive or administrative
post.


4. Negroes concede that TV
networks and some producers are
making a concerted effort to show
Negroes in typical, every day
activities.


S. Most Negro actors and tech
n1cians contacted in the survey
are not SO optimistic as to be-
lieve that next season or the i'm
mediate future will bring them
major gains.


Most Negro leaders. however,
think that the progress to date
has been slower than 1t should
be. "Television is growing as far
as the image of the Negro is
concerned. Still. 1t has a long
way to CO." said Jesse H. Walk
err, city editor of the New York
Amsterdam News. Negro news
paper.

The summer schedule for
city pools is: noon until 9 p.m.,
on weekdays, and from 10 am.
pm. on Saturdays, Sundays and
holidays at the following pools:


Coronado, IL. st and Coronad
Encanto, Is Ave. and Encanto;
Falcon, 35 Ave. and Roosevelt;
Holiday, 81 Ave. and Minnezona
which is closed Mondays; Madi-
son, 16 St. and Glenrosa; Mary
vale, 81 Ave. and Missouri;
Maryvale Park, 81 Ave. and
Campbell; Perry, 80 St. and
Windsor; Roosevelt, So. 7 st.
and Alta Vista; Starlight, 1910
w. Osborn which is also closed
on Mondays; Sunnyslope, 301 w.
Dunlap; University, 10 Ave. and
w. Van Buren, and Washington,
% Ave. and Ocotillo.


The following pools will open
and noon and evening hours will
vary.


Alkire, II Ave. and Papago;
Harmon, 5 Ave. and Yavapi; East
lake, 16 St. and E. Jeffer son
which is open from noon to 7
pm. everyday, except Tuesday
nooll until 10 pm. Grant, 2 Ave.
and Grant, and is closed Sundays.


Schedule for the wading pools
will be as follows:


10 am. $3.50 pm. weekdays,
10 am. = l pm. Saturdays and
closed Sundays for Central, First
St. and Tonic; Harmon, Ave.
and Yavapai; Grant, 2 Ave. and
Grant and Verde, 9 St. and Polk.
Univer sity, 10 Ave. and w. Van
Buren, is open II am. = pm.
daily except Fridays when it is
closed. Townsend, 5 st. and
Mcdowell, is open daily from
10 am. until 1880 pm. and closed
Sundays.


Morning swimming classes
will be offered from 10 am.
to noon. Local pool managers
should be contac ted for further
information.

SAN FRANCISCO Willie
Mays, SO yr. old star center
fielder, was named field captain
Of the San Francisco Giants re-
Gently.


In making appointment Giants
Manager Alvin Dark said, Willie
Mays 10 managerial material"


The baseball player commen-
ted, IL am very proud to be cap
tain"

Willie Mays Named
Giants Team Captain

Tommie May Boone l3. is the
Arizona Teen of the Week. Tom
ME, the daughter Of Mr.. and
Mrs. Tommie Boone, 1911 S.
18th Street, was one of the top
graduates Of Palmdale Elemen-
tary School. She won two schol-
arship awards.


An energetic young girl, Tom
ME likes all kinds of sports and
she plays the flute.


She plans to be social work.
er when she completes college.

1905 w. Buckeye
